message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The SCIP Optimization Suite 7.0
Paper Abstract: The SCIP Optimization Suite provides a collection of software packages for mathematical optimization centered around the constraint integer programming framework SCIP. This paper discusses enhancements and extensions contained in version 7.0 of the SCIP Optimization Suite. The new version features the parallel presolving library PaPILO as a new addition to the suite. PaPILO 1.0 simplifies mixed-integer linear optimization problems and can be used stand-alone or integrated into SCIP via a presolver plugin. SCIP 7.0 provides additional support for decomposition algorithms. Besides improvements in the Benders’ decomposition solver of SCIP, user-defined decomposition structures can be read, which are used by the automated Benders’ decomposition solver and two primal heuristics. Additionally, SCIP 7.0 comes with a tree size estimation that is used to predict the completion of the overall solving process and potentially trigger restarts. Moreover, substantial performance improvements of the MIP core were achieved by new developments in presolving, primal heuristics, branching rules, conflict analysis, and symmetry handling. Last, not least, the report presents updates to other components and extensions of the SCIP Optimization Suite, in particular, the LP solver SoPlex and the mixed-integer semidefinite programming solver SCIP-SDP.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Semidefinite Programming

Semidefinite programming (SDP) is a subfield of mathematical programming concerned with the optimization of a linear objective function over the intersection of the cone of positive semidefinite matrices with an affine space.

### Key Characteristics

SDPs are a special case of cone programming and can be efficiently solved by interior point methods.(no content)All linear programs and convex quadratic programs can be expressed as SDPs, and via hierarchies of SDPs the solutions of polynomial optimization problems can be approximated.

### Applications

Many practical problems in operations research and combinatorial optimization can be modeled or approximated as semidefinite programming problems.(no content)In automatic control theory, SDPs are used in the context of linear matrix inequalities. Additionally, semidefinite programs are important tools for developing approximation algorithms for NP-hard maximization problems.(no content)Semidefinite programming has been applied to find approximate solutions to combinatorial optimization problems, such as the solution of the max cut problem with an approximation ratio of 0.87856.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's what I found about mixed-integer linear programming:

## Definition

If only some of the unknown variables are required to be integers, then the problem is called a mixed integer (linear) programming (MIP or MILP) problem. Alternatively, if some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Applications

Mixed-integer programming has many applications in industrial productions, including job-shop modelling. Specific applications include:

- **Agricultural production**: Agricultural production planning involving determining production yield for several crops that can share resources (e.g. land, labor, capital, seeds, fertilizer, etc.), with a possible objective to maximize the total production without exceeding the available resources.

- **Transportation**: Service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks, such as assigning buses or subways to individual routes to meet a timetable and equip them with drivers.

- **Telecommunications**: Frequency planning in GSM mobile networks involves distributing available frequencies across antennas, formulated as an integer linear program in which binary variables indicate whether a frequency is assigned to an antenna.

## Solution Methods

Cutting plane methods work by solving the LP relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer.(no content)Other algorithms include variants of the branch and bound method, such as the branch and cut method that combines both approaches.

Based on the search results, I found some relevant information about presolving in optimization. One result mentions that LP presolve was combined with other techniques in the HiGHS optimization solver's origins to solve industrial LP problems faster than the best open-source solvers.

However, the search results provided general information about optimization methods and solvers rather than a detailed explanation of presolving itself. 

**Presolving** (or "presolver") is a preprocessing technique used in mathematical optimization, particularly in linear programming (LP) and mixed-integer programming (MIP). It works by simplifying an optimization problem before the main solver runs, through techniques such as:

- Removing redundant constraints
- Fixing variables with bound implications
- Simplifying coefficient matrices
- Reducing problem size and complexity

This preprocessing step can significantly improve solver performance by reducing the problem size and difficulty before the actual solution algorithm begins, which is why it was valued as a key component in developing faster LP solvers.

If you'd like more specific technical details about presolving techniques or its applications in particular solvers, I'd be happy to search for more targeted information.

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_programming"},{"title":"Constraint logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_logic_programming"},{"title":"Quadratically constrained quadratic program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratically_constrained_quadratic_program"},{"title":"Constrained optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constrained_optimization"},{"title":"Zuse Institute Berlin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zuse_Institute_Berlin"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"OR-Tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR-Tools"},{"title":"Constraint (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binding_constraint"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"}]

Here are the results for the query "constraint integer programming":

## Overview

An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers. In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.

## Key Characteristics

Integer programming is NP-complete, making it computationally challenging to solve.

If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Solution Methods

One class of algorithms are cutting plane methods, which work by solving the LP relaxation and then adding linear constraints that drive the solution towards being integer without excluding any integer feasible points.(no content)Another class of algorithms are variants of the branch and bound method. For example, the branch and cut method that combines both branch and bound and cutting plane methods.

## Applications

Constraint integer programming has practical applications in various fields, including frequency planning in GSM mobile networks, which can be formulated as an integer linear program in which binary variables indicate whether a frequency is assigned to an antenna.

## Related Tools

SCIP (Solving Constraint Integer Programs) is a mixed integer programming solver and a framework for branch and cut and branch and price, developed primarily at Zuse Institute Berlin.

Links: [{"title":"Benders decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benders_decomposition"},{"title":"FortSP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FortSP"},{"title":"Jacques F. Benders - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_F._Benders"},{"title":"Category:Decomposition methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Decomposition_methods"},{"title":"Benders (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benders_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Bender's method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bender's_method"},{"title":"B-Bender - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/StringBender"},{"title":"Benderama - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benderama"},{"title":"Decomposition of a module - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decomposition_of_a_module"},{"title":"Benders (TV series) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benders_(TV_series)"}]

## Benders Decomposition

Benders decomposition is a technique in mathematical programming that allows the solution of very large linear programming problems that have a special block structure.(no content)This block structure often occurs in applications such as stochastic programming as the uncertainty is usually represented with scenarios.

### How It Works

The strategy behind Benders decomposition can be summarized as divide-and-conquer, where the variables of the original problem are divided into two subsets so that a first-stage master problem is solved over the first set of variables, and the values for the second set of variables are determined in a second-stage subproblem for a given first-stage solution.(no content)If the subproblem determines that the fixed first-stage decisions are in fact infeasible, then so-called Benders cuts are generated and added to the master problem, which is then re-solved until no cuts can be generated.(no content)Since Benders decomposition adds new constraints as it progresses towards a solution, the approach is called "row generation".

### History

The technique is named after Jacques F. Benders.(no content)He worked at Shell laboratory in Amsterdam where he researched mathematical programming problems concerning the logistics of oil refinery and developed the technique known as Benders' decomposition, which he used in his doctoral thesis.

## Benders Decomposition

Benders decomposition is a technique in mathematical programming that allows the solution of very large linear programming problems that have a special block structure.(no content)This block structure often occurs in applications such as stochastic programming as the uncertainty is usually represented with scenarios.

### How It Works

The strategy behind Benders decomposition can be summarized as divide-and-conquer, where the variables of the original problem are divided into two subsets so that a first-stage master problem is solved over the first set of variables, and the values for the second set of variables are determined in a second-stage subproblem for a given first-stage solution.(no content)If the subproblem determines that the fixed first-stage decisions are in fact infeasible, then so-called Benders cuts are generated and added to the master problem, which is then re-solved until no cuts can be generated.(no content)Since Benders decomposition adds new constraints as it progresses towards a solution, the approach is called "row generation".

### History

The technique is named after Jacques F. Benders.(no content)He worked at Shell laboratory in Amsterdam where he researched mathematical programming problems concerning the logistics of oil refinery and developed the technique known as Benders' decomposition, which he used in his doctoral thesis.

## Results for "Linear Programming"

I found comprehensive information about linear programming. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Purpose

Linear programming (LP), also called linear optimization, is a method to achieve the best outcome (such as maximum profit or lowest cost) in a mathematical model whose requirements and objective are represented by linear relationships. More formally, linear programming is a technique for the optimization of a linear objective function, subject to linear equality and linear inequality constraints.

### How It Works

Its feasible region is a convex polytope defined as the intersection of finitely many half spaces, each defined by a linear inequality, with an objective function that is a real-valued affine function defined on this polytope. A linear programming algorithm finds a point in the polytope where this function has the largest (or smallest) value if such a point exists.

### Real-World Applications

Industries that use linear programming models include transportation, energy, telecommunications, and manufacturing. It has proven useful in modeling diverse types of problems in planning, routing, scheduling, assignment, and design.

### Historical Development

From 1946 to 1947 George B. Dantzig independently developed general linear programming formulation to use for planning problems in the US Air Force. In 1947, Dantzig also invented the simplex method that, for the first time efficiently, tackled the linear programming problem in most cases.

### Key Principle

The maxima and minima of a linear function over a convex polygonal region occur at the region's corners.

Links: [{"title":"Heuristic (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Metaheuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaheuristic"},{"title":"Heuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic"},{"title":"Mathematical optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_optimization"},{"title":"Category:Heuristic algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Heuristic_algorithms"},{"title":"Greedy algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greedy_algorithm"},{"title":"List of metaphor-based metaheuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_metaphor-based_metaheuristics"},{"title":"Table of metaheuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Table_of_metaheuristics"},{"title":"Matheuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matheuristics"},{"title":"Local search (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_search_(optimization)"}]

Here's an overview of heuristic algorithm optimization based on the search results:

## What Are Heuristic Algorithms?

A heuristic technique is any approach to problem solving that employs a pragmatic method that is not fully optimized, perfected, or rationalized, but is nevertheless "good enough" as an approximation or attribute substitution.(no content)A heuristic is any algorithm which is not guaranteed (mathematically) to find the solution, but which is nevertheless useful in certain practical situations.

## Importance in Optimization

Results about NP-hardness in theoretical computer science make heuristics the only viable option for a variety of complex optimization problems that need to be routinely solved in real-world applications.(no content)Heuristics are used to find approximate solutions for many complicated optimization problems.

## Metaheuristics

A metaheuristic is a higher-level procedure or heuristic designed to find, generate, tune, or select a heuristic that may provide a sufficiently good solution to an optimization problem, especially with incomplete or imperfect information or limited computation capacity.

Common metaheuristics include:
- Simulated annealing, tabu search, iterated local search, variable neighborhood search, and GRASP
- Ant colony optimization, evolutionary computation such as genetic algorithm or evolution strategies, particle swarm optimization, rider optimization algorithm and bacterial foraging algorithm

## Local Search

Local search is a heuristic method for solving computationally hard optimization problems.(no content)A local search algorithm starts from a candidate solution and then iteratively moves to a neighboring solution; a neighborhood being the set of all potential solutions that differ from the current solution by the minimal possible extent.

Here's what I found about integer programming:

## Definition

An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers.(no content)In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.

## Key Variants

- 0–1 integer programming or binary integer programming (BIP) is the special case of integer programming where variables are required to be 0 or 1 (rather than arbitrary integers).
- If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Computational Complexity

Integer programming is NP-complete, and in many practical situations (those with bounded variables) integer programming problems are NP-hard.

## Applications

The integer variables represent quantities that can only be integer. For example, it is not possible to build 3.7 cars. Other common applications include service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks. For example, a problem may involve assigning buses or subways to individual routes so that a timetable can be met, and also to equip them with drivers.

## Solution Methods

Cutting planes were proposed by Ralph Gomory in the 1950s as a method for solving integer programming and mixed-integer programming problems. In the mid-1990s Gérard Cornuéjols and co-workers showed them to be very effective in combination with branch-and-bound (called branch-and-cut).

Here's what I found about integer programming:

## Definition

An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers.(no content)In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.

## Key Variants

- 0–1 integer programming or binary integer programming (BIP) is the special case of integer programming where variables are required to be 0 or 1 (rather than arbitrary integers).
- If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

## Computational Complexity

Integer programming is NP-complete, and in many practical situations (those with bounded variables) integer programming problems are NP-hard.

## Applications

The integer variables represent quantities that can only be integer. For example, it is not possible to build 3.7 cars. Other common applications include service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks. For example, a problem may involve assigning buses or subways to individual routes so that a timetable can be met, and also to equip them with drivers.

## Solution Methods

Cutting planes were proposed by Ralph Gomory in the 1950s as a method for solving integer programming and mixed-integer programming problems. In the mid-1990s Gérard Cornuéjols and co-workers showed them to be very effective in combination with branch-and-bound (called branch-and-cut).

Based on the search results, here's what I found about symmetry breaking optimization:

## Symmetry-Breaking Constraints in Combinatorial Optimization

In combinatorial optimization, the method of symmetry-breaking constraints can be used to take advantage of symmetries in many constraint satisfaction and optimization problems, by adding constraints that eliminate symmetries and reduce the search space size.

This is a practical technique used to improve the efficiency of optimization algorithms by identifying and exploiting the symmetric properties of problems, thereby narrowing down the solution space that needs to be explored.

The search results primarily focus on symmetry-breaking constraints as an optimization technique rather than the broader physics concept of symmetry breaking (which appears in quantum field theory, condensed matter physics, and biology). If you're looking for information about a specific application of symmetry breaking in optimization—such as in constraint satisfaction problems, scheduling, or machine learning—feel free to ask for more details!

Links: [{"title":"Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"Talk:Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"Plane (tool) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plane_(tool)"},{"title":"Stretched grid method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stretched_grid_method"},{"title":"Adrian Baddeley - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adrian_Baddeley"}]

Here's what I found about the cutting plane method:

## Overview

In mathematical optimization, the cutting-plane method is any of a variety of optimization methods that iteratively refine a feasible set or objective function by means of linear inequalities, termed cuts.

## Applications

These methods are commonly used to find integer solutions to mixed integer linear programming (MILP) problems, as well as to solve general, not necessarily differentiable convex optimization problems.

## History

Cutting planes were proposed by Ralph Gomory in the 1950s as a method for solving integer programming and mixed-integer programming problems.(no content)Nowadays, all commercial MILP solvers use Gomory cuts in one way or another.

## How It Works

Cutting plane methods for MILP work by solving a non-integer linear program, the linear relaxation of the given integer program.

## Other Variants

Cutting-plane methods for general convex continuous optimization are known under various names including Kelley's method and bundle methods, and are popularly used for non-differentiable convex minimization.

Links: [{"title":"Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Branch and price - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_price"},{"title":"Joint compatibility branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_compatibility_branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Travelling salesman problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem"},{"title":"Talk:Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Talk:Uniform-cost search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Uniform-cost_search"},{"title":"B* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B*"},{"title":"Shifting bottleneck heuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shifting_bottleneck_heuristic"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about the branch and bound algorithm:

## Overview

Branch-and-bound (BB, B&B, or BnB) is a method for solving optimization problems by breaking them down into smaller subproblems and using a bounding function to eliminate subproblems that cannot contain the optimal solution.(no content)It is an algorithm design paradigm for discrete and combinatorial optimization problems, as well as mathematical optimization.

## How It Works

A branch-and-bound algorithm consists of a systematic enumeration of candidate solutions by means of state-space search, where the set of candidate solutions is thought of as forming a rooted tree with the full set at the root, and the algorithm explores branches of this tree, which represent subsets of the solution set.(no content)Before enumerating the candidate solutions of a branch, the branch is checked against upper and lower estimated bounds on the optimal solution, and is discarded if it cannot produce a better solution than the best one found so far by the algorithm.(no content)To improve on the performance of brute-force search, a B&B algorithm keeps track of bounds on the minimum that it is trying to find, and uses these bounds to "prune" the search space, eliminating candidate solutions that it can prove will not contain an optimal solution.

## Historical Background

The method was first proposed by Ailsa Land and Alison Doig whilst carrying out research at the London School of Economics sponsored by British Petroleum in 1960 for discrete programming, and has become the most commonly used tool for solving NP-hard optimization problems.(no content)The name "branch and bound" first occurred in the work of Little et al. on the traveling salesman problem.

## Applications

The algorithm is widely used in solving combinatorial optimization problems, including the traveling salesman problem, integer linear programming, and various scheduling problems.

A branch-and-bound algorithm consists of a systematic enumeration of candidate solutions by means of state-space search, where the set of candidate solutions is thought of as forming a rooted tree with the full set at the root, and the algorithm explores branches of this tree, which represent subsets of the solution set.(no content)Before enumerating the candidate solutions of a branch, the branch is checked against upper and lower estimated bounds on the optimal solution, and is discarded if it cannot produce a better solution than the best one found so far by the algorithm.(no content)To improve on the performance of brute-force search, a B&B algorithm keeps track of bounds on the minimum that it is trying to find, and uses these bounds to "prune" the search space, eliminating candidate solutions that it can prove will not contain an optimal solution.

## Historical Background

The method was first proposed by Ailsa Land and Alison Doig whilst carrying out research at the London School of Economics sponsored by British Petroleum in 1960 for discrete programming, and has become the most commonly used tool for solving NP-hard optimization problems.(no content)The name "branch and bound" first occurred in the work of Little et al. on the traveling salesman problem.

## Applications

The algorithm is widely used in solving combinatorial optimization problems, including the traveling salesman problem, integer linear programming, and various scheduling problems.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about mathematical optimization:

## Definition and Overview

Mathematical optimization (alternatively spelled optimisation) or mathematical programming is the selection of a best element, with regard to some criteria, from some set of available alternatives.(no content)It involves the theory and computation of extrema or stationary points of functions.

## Main Subfields

Mathematical optimization is generally divided into two subfields: discrete optimization and continuous optimization.(no content)In discrete optimization, some or all of the variables are restricted to be discrete variables—that is, to assume only a discrete set of values, such as the integers.

## Key Approaches and Methods

Several important approaches exist within mathematical optimization:

- **Linear Programming**: The term "linear programming" was due to George B. Dantzig, although much of the theory had been introduced by Leonid Kantorovich in 1939.

- **Combinatorial Optimization**: This subfield consists of finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects, where typical problems include the travelling salesman problem, the minimum spanning tree problem, and the knapsack problem.

- **Constrained Optimization**: This is the process of optimizing an objective function with respect to some variables in the presence of constraints on those variables.

- **Dynamic Programming**: This approach solves stochastic optimization problems by splitting the problem into smaller subproblems.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
